qas.question: How long is a movie typically released in theaters for?
During this time, how are digital versions of the movie transported in data storage devices?
What can be done to a movie to only allow it to show at certain times?
What can be coded to films to find the source of illegal copies?
What inferior versions of movies are available for piracy during the theatrical run of a movie called?

answers.text: "cams" made by video recordings of the movie screens

qas.question: How long is a movie atypically released in theaters for?
During this time, how aren't digital versions of the movie transported in data storage devices?
What can't be done to a movie to only allow it to show at certain times?
What can be coded to films to find the source of legal copies?

plausible_answers.text: "cams" made by video recordings of the movie screens

qas.question: What superior versions of movies are available for piracy during the theatrical run of a movie called?

context: To prevent piracy of films, the standard drill of film distribution is to have a movie first released through movie theaters (theatrical window), on average <a0_0>approximately <b5_0>16 and a half weeks<b5_0/><a0_0/>, before having it released to Blu-Ray and DVD (entering its video window). During the theatrical window, digital versions of films are often transported in data storage devices <a1_0><b6_0>by couriers<b6_0/><a1_0/> rather than by data transmission. The data can be <a2_0><b7_0>encrypted<b7_0/><a2_0/>, with the key being made to work only at specific times in order to prevent leakage between screens. Coded <a3_0><b8_0>Anti-Piracy marks can be added<b8_0/><a3_0/> to films to identify the source of illegal copies and shut them down. As a result of these measures, the only versions of films available for piracy during the theatrical window are usually <a4_0><b9_0>"cams" made by video recordings of the movie screens<b9_0/><a4_0/>, which are of inferior quality compared to the original film version.
